items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from overnight tonight, Monday 18/11/24.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
Rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on Tuesday 19/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Monday 18th November, and for at least the next 24hrs. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect, and tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.    Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 19th November.

items.description: East Somerset Rivers

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Lovington river gauge as a result of overnight rainfall.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible when river levels are at their highest from 6:00 AM on 19/11/2024.
Areas most at risk include the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road.  Overtopping is forecast from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay.  The River Brue is forecast to be bankfull upstream of Bruton Dam with field flooding likely.
Weather conditions are expected to improve this morning and no further flooding is expected.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Refer to local authority website for road closures.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 19/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60mAOD at 04:15 on 19/11/2024.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 62 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 19/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Tuesday's early morning tide at 01:00 on 19/11/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.37 m. The total forecast tide is 6.19 metres Chart Datum (3.14 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields, including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:15 (19/11/2024) is forecast to be 5 cm lower (3.09 mAOD). Similar impacts are expected during Tuesday afternoon's tide. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 19/11/2024.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Tuesday's early morning tide at 01:00 on 19/11/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.37 m. The total forecast tide is 6.19 metres Chart Datum (3.14 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high water, the tide could cause flooding to boatyards and the industrial areas along Littlehampton Rope Walk. Water will be high up slipways and could be forced up through drains causing minor flooding to roads. If the tide is slightly higher than forecast, following flood damage in April 2024, it could be possible for a small amount of water to flow through The Shipyard, and onto Rope Walk. Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:15 (19/11/2024) is forecast to be 5 cm lower (3.09 mAOD), with minimal flood impacts expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 2 hours before high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 19/11/2024.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message: A higher than normal tide tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. The highest tide level is expected to be at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon at 11:17AM on 19/11/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. We are closely monitoring the situation. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as waves and sea spray could be dangerous. The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Christchurch Harbour at 11:17 AM on 19/11/2024 with a level of 1.20 mAODN with a Northerly force 4 wind. This is the threshold for issuing the Flood Alert for Christchurch Harbour. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 19/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides. Light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island tomorrow morning (19/11/2024) at 04:30, and is forecast to reach between 4.67m and 4.81m. The following high tide on Tuesday afternoon (19/11/2024) at 17:00, is forecast to reach between 4.87m and 5.01m. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible for these tides.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High tides and forecast weather conditions may lead to flooding from sea spray and wave overtopping. Flooding is possible on Tuesday 19/11/2024, between 06:45 and 09:45. Areas most at risk include exposed locations near to the North Sea coast and around Spurn Road. We are closely monitoring the situation. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Tuesday 19/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:00 on 19/11/2024 is higher than normal, with light North Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.44 m. The total forecast tide is 5.20 metres Chart Datum (2.47 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Impacts will be relatively minor and confined to the immediate sea front. For 30 minutes either side of high tide, water will be high at South Street and Queen Street, Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park, Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the road at Langstone High Street, but flood depths will be relatively shallow. Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:15 (20/11/2024) is forecast to be 49 cm lower (1.98 mAOD). No further flood impacts are expected. If you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will remove this message by 16:00 on 19/11/2024.

items.message:

The next high tide at London Bridge at 03:15 on 19/11/2024, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 62 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 19/11/2024, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
The tidal alert for the Somerset Coast at Porlock Weir has been removed. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The weather is more settled, high tides are falling and no flooding is expected. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flood Alert has been issued due to a high tide forecast for tomorrow afternoon, 19/11/24. High water levels are expected to affect the foreshore on the Isle of Sheppey and the Coast from Kemsley to Seasalter. Tides will be at their highest between 11:00 and 16:00, with high tide expected at 14:15. Expect tides to be higher than usual.
Flooding to the foreshore and low lying land is possible at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated after 24 hours, 17:00 on 19/11/24, or as the situation changes. For those that use it, the astronomical level at 14:15 will be 2.86mAOD and the total water level will be 3.44mAOD.
